title: Ant and Dec launch mental health campaign on BGT: The Champions
text:
Ant and Dec paused the action on Britain’s Got Talent (Picture: ITV)

Ant and Dec paused Britain’s Got Talent: The Champions final on Saturday to launch a new mental wellness campaign.

Following an emotional performance by dance crew Mersey Girls, the hosts appeared on stage with an important announcement for everyone watching on at home.

Discussing the new campaign, Declan Donnelly, 44, said: ‘We’d like to introduce the new ITV campaign for mental wellness, right here on Britain’s Got Talent tonight.

‘In the last 15 years, there has been a staggering 48% rise in anxiety and depression amongst British children, but something as simple as talking together and listening to each other can build our mental wellness.’

Co-host Ant McPartlin, 43, continued: ‘Now, we all know that these days there are more distractions than ever because we’re looking at the telly or we’re looking at our phones.

‘But it’s so important for our mental wellbeing to remember to get together and with people we care about and talk.’

Flash cards were held up during the break (Picture: ITV)

Launching the initiative, Dec explained they were doing something that they had never done before – pausing the show so those at home could have a quick chat.

‘So right now, we’re going to try something that has never been done before, it’s called Britain Get Talking,’ he said.

‘And to help Britain get talking, we’re going to pause the show to make time for everyone there at home to get together and just talk.

‘We’re pausing BGT for a minute so you can talk.’

Dec sought therapy after Ant’s drink-driving conviction (Picture: Getty)

As silence filled the room, signs flashed up, encouraging everyone to speak to each other.

The hosts then signalled the end of the silence, with Simon Cowell up on his feet applauding the pair, as well as the audience.

Dec added: ‘Seriously though, just taking time to talk with your nearest and dearest can really make a difference, especially for young people.

‘So please make sure tonight is just the start. Britain, Get Talking.’

The dad-of-one has previously opened up about his mental health, explaining that he sought therapy after Ant’s drink-driving conviction last year.

His best pal pleaded guilty to a charge of drink-driving, and was fined £86,000 and banned from driving for 20 months, after a three-way car crash.

He later went to rehab for a second time, after a previous stint in 2017.

And, speaking about the incident, Dec told The Guardian: ‘It’s the most destabilising thing that has ever happened to me.

‘I had some counselling, and I still do. Just counselling. Therapy. It helps to talk to somebody independent, who doesn’t watch or care about TV.

‘We just sit and talk for an hour.’

For more information on Britain Get Talking, visit itv.com/britaingettalking.

Need support? Contact the Samaritans For emotional support you can call the Samaritans 24-hour helpline on 116 123, email jo@samaritans.org, visit a Samaritans branch in person or go to the Samaritans website.
